content: SECTION 1. CASA GRANDE RUINS BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENT. The Casa Grande Ruins National Monument Boundary Modification Act of 2004 renamed the Casa Grande Ruin Reservation to Casa Grande Ruins National Monument, which protects a significant archaeological site of the 13th Century Hohokam culture in the American Southwest. The Casa Grande Ruins National Monument Boundary Modification Act of 2004 aims to expand the monument's boundary to protect newly discovered sites associated with the existing monument and to enhance our understanding of the ancient Hohokam culture in the American Southwest. This expansion will also provide more opportunities for visitors, researchers, and the surrounding area. The Casa Grande Ruins National Monument Boundary Modification Act of 2004 aims to expand the monument's boundary to protect newly discovered sites associated with the existing monument and enhance understanding of the ancient Hohokam culture. This includes transferring jurisdiction of land for the San Carlos Irrigation Project and clarifying ownership of land on the monument's southwest boundary. The Casa Grande Ruins National Monument Boundary Modification Act of 2004 aims to expand the monument's boundary by acquiring lands owned by the State of Arizona for the Casa Grande Ruins National Monument. The Map depicting the proposed boundary modification is available for inspection, and the added lands will be administered by the Secretary in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. The Casa Grande Ruins National Monument Boundary Modification Act of 2004 allows for the acquisition of lands owned by the State of Arizona or private landowners with their consent and in accordance with State and Federal law. Lands under the jurisdiction of a Federal agency other than the Department of the Interior may be transferred to the Secretary with the consent of the head of the agency. The lands on the Map include 80 acres of privately owned land, 7.4 acres of Federal land known as the Horvath Site, and 3 parcels totaling 43.42 acres. The Casa Grande Ruins National Monument Boundary Modification Act of 2004 allows for the acquisition of State and private lands with fair compensation. This includes 3 parcels totaling 43.42 acres owned by the Archeological Conservancy, 4.5 acres of Federal land, and 126 acres of State land known as Adamsville. The Secretary will pay fair market value for acquired lands unless they are donated. Transfer of approximately 3.75 acres of Federal land in Arizona from the National Park Service to the Bureau of Indian Affairs for widening and paving the San Carlos Irrigation Project.
